awd_titl_txt: CAREER:  Human motor inhibition: a neural race between motor emission and cognitive control
awd_abstract_narration:
The ability to rapidly stop one's actions even after their initiation is paramount to survival in modern society. Be it in benign scenarios (checking the swing of a baseball bat) or in life-threatening scenarios, rapid action-stopping is a core human ability that is highly relevant in everyday life. In this project, Dr. Wessel will use neural recordings and brain stimulation in adult healthy humans to further our understanding of how brain activity underlying motor emission (initiating an action) and motor inhibition (stopping that action) interact during the rapid stopping of action. Elucidating the neural interactions underlying action-stopping will inform our basic understanding of flexible behavior in both health and disease. This is especially relevant since action-stopping is significantly impaired across many neuropsychiatric disorders. During this project, Dr. Wessel will implement an educational opportunity at his institution that aims to provide a first-hand research experience in human neuroscience to first-generation college students, a population that is traditionally underrepresented in basic academic science and the STEM workforce.

The ability to stop the execution of an already initiated action is a key cognitive control ability. In prominent theoretical models, stopping is conceptualized as a race between a "go"-process and a separate "stop"-process that races to intercept the go-process. While extensive past research has established that a fronto-basal ganglia brain network implements the "stop" side of this equation, human research has so far fallen short of demonstrating the existence of an actual race between separate stop- and a go-processes in the brain. By combining measurements of intra- / extracranial electroencephalography and cortico-spinal excitability with brain stimulation, the project aims to elucidate neural concomitants of the purported race on all levels of processing (motor, cortical, subcortical). First, a pure neural measurement of the stopping process will be identified by disentangling neural processes that reflect stop-signal detection from those that reflect the stop-process itself. Second, this signature of the stop-process and an according measurement of the go-process will be used to predict behavior based on the trial-by-trial outcome of their neural race. Third, cortical and subcortical nodes of the neural network underlying the stop-process will be disrupted using transcranial magnetic and deep-brain stimulation to test the hypothesis that such disruptions impair motor inhibition specifically by biasing the race towards the "go" process.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This work had three overarching scientific goals. First, we aimed to establish novel neural markers of the brain’s inhibitory motor control mechanism – the mechanism that allows humans to abort an already initiated action, such as stopping to walk into a street when seeing a car bearing down. This control process is vital, as it is impaired in a large group of neuropsychiatric disorders, ranging from Parkinson’s Disease to ADHD. In this regard, this proposal was successful in several ways. It identified a new EEG biomarker of the engagement of this control process during action-stopping, while ensuring that this activity could not be explained by other processes necessary to stop an action (such as recognizing that control is needed in the first place). It furthermore generated a new way to measure the effects of this inhibitory brain mechanism on the motor system without having to rely on brain stimulation (which was previously necessary), solely by measuring changes in isometrically (steadily) exerted motoric force. The second goal was to develop a new, comprehensive theoretical model of the processes involved in action-stopping. Existing models had failed to account for recent empirical findings. Our new model, which suggests that two separate, sequential inhibitory control processes contribute to successful action-stopping, can reconcile these views and has already proven to be influential in generating novel work in the field. The third goal was to generate causal evidence for this very model. We did so by using both electrical and transcranial magnetic brain stimulation. By interrupting the activity of the brain mechanism underlying inhibitory control at different nodes (i.e., in different brain regions that comprise the network implementing the mechanism), we could directly and causally test the prediction of our two-stage model. We found that the subthalamic nucleus, a small area in the human basal ganglia, is responsible for implementing the first inhibitory process – one that rapidly and pauses all ongoing behavior when the need for rapid action-stopping is recognized. We furthermore found that the cortical pre-supplementary motor area is key in implementing the second inhibitory process, which is slower and more strategic. Temporarily disabling the pre-SMA via transcranial magnetic stimulation led to excess, uninhibited motor activity that remained after the initial inhibitory control exerted by the subthalamic nucleus. Taken together, this work has generated a fundamentally novel understanding of the neural processes underlying inhibitory motor control and action-stopping. Both the theoretical model and the empirical signatures derived from this work will be useful in motivating and informing future research across the field of human motor control. As such, all three scientific goals of this proposal have been successfully achieved. In the process, this work has also generated the largest publicly available dataset of humans performing an action-stopping motor control task while undergoing neural recordings. These data have already been used by multiple other groups to test and generate novel hypotheses regarding the neural mechanisms underlying human motor control.

 

Beyond these scientific achievements, the goal was to establish a brain research workshop at the University of Iowa targeted at first-generation college graduates (i.e., students whose parents, like the PI of this proposal, did not obtain college degrees). This group is historically and acutely underrepresented in academic research. This award-winning workshop has been held at the University of Iowa four times since award of this grant, reaching a total of over 50 students in a four-day, intensive, hands-on program. Students learned the most common research techniques in cognitive neuroscience and heard presentations from UI faculty that use these techniques, as well as presentations from other groups on campus that have resources for undergraduates interested in performing scientific research during the degree at the UI. We will continue this workshop going forward using discretionary funds obtained by the PI.
